name: Desert Varnish
summary: Dark coating on rocks created by microscopic bacteria over thousands of years.
description: Desert varnish (also called rock varnish) is the dark, shiny coating visible on many rock surfaces in the desert Southwest. Despite its geological appearance, desert varnish is actually a biogeochemical phenomenon created by microbial life. The coating is extremely thin—usually less than a millimeter—but consists of clay minerals cemented together with manganese and iron oxides. The dark coloration comes primarily from manganese, which makes up 30-70% of the varnish. For over a century, scientists debated how desert varnish forms. Current research shows that specialized bacteria concentrate manganese and iron from tiny amounts dissolved in water (dew, rain, fog) on the rock surface. These microbes oxidize the metals and produce the varnish as a metabolic byproduct. Desert varnish forms incredibly slowly—it can take thousands of years to develop a thick coating, making varnished surfaces valuable for dating rock art and surface features. Indigenous peoples recognized that freshly chipped rock surfaces contrast sharply with dark varnished surfaces, using this principle to create petroglyphs that remain visible for millennia. Desert varnish also preserves a chemical record of past climates and environmental conditions.
safety: Desert varnish itself is harmless, but never deface or remove it from rocks. Doing so destroys irreplaceable archaeological and scientific records. Petroglyphs covered with desert varnish are legally protected cultural resources.
fun_fact: Desert varnish can preserve organic compounds trapped in its layers for thousands of years. Scientists analyze trapped pollen and other materials to reconstruct ancient climates. Some of the oldest desert varnish in the world is found in the Atacama Desert and may be over 100,000 years old!
